item.title: About R & RStudio
item.description:
• ¿What is R?
  • The R software environment
  • Why use R?
  • ¿What is RStudio?
  • Definitions
  • Installing and Loading Packages

¿What is R?

R is a language and software environment for statistical computing and graphics.

R provides a wide variety of statistical and graphical techniques, and is highly extensible.

It is one of the most popular languages used by statisticians, data analysts, researchers and marketers to retrieve, clean, analyze, visualize and present data.

The R software environment

The R language programming environment is a fully planned and coherent system built around a standard command-line interface. Users leverage this to read data and load it to the workspace, specify commands and receive results.

Why use R?

  • R is open-source and free!

  • R is popular and R community is huge

  • R runs on all platforms (Available for Windows, Macintosh, and Linux).

  • Publication-quality graphs. With R you have complete control over plotting/graphing options and are able to output publication quality figures with ease.

  • Packages for literate statistical programming - weaving written reports and analysis code in one document.

  • It’s fun… probably not at the beginning of the learning process.

Credits: allison_horst

¿What is RStudio?

RStudio is a free, open source IDE (integrated development environment) for R. Its interface is organized so that the user can clearly view graphs, data tables, R code, and output all at the same time. It also offers an Import-Wizard-like feature that allows users to import CSV, Excel, SAS, SPSS and Stata files into R without having to write the code to do so.

It is important to note that RStudio is a software that runs R and provides additional tools that are useful when writing R code. So R and RStudio are not the same.

Definitions

The following concepts will be helpful as you begin to explore the R world.

  • CRAN: The Comprehensive R Archive Network is a network of web servers around the world that store identical, up-to-date, versions of code and documentation for R.

  • R packages: Extensions to the R programming language. R packages contain code, data, and documentation in a standardised collection format that can be installed by users of R, typically via a centralised software repository such as CRAN. The location where the packages are stored is called the library. If there is a particular functionality that you require, you can download the package from the appropriate site and it will be stored in your library.

  • Function: is a set of statements organized together to perform a specific task. R has a large number of in-built functions and the user can create their own functions.

Installing and Loading Packages

In order to use a package, it needs to be installed on your computer by running install.packages("name_of_package") (do not forget "" around the name of the package).

Once the package is installed, you must load the package and only after it has been loaded you can use all the functions and datasets it contains. To load a package, run library(name_of_package) (this time "" around the name of the package are optional).

item.title: Data Set
item.description:
• Context
  • Content
  • Data Dictionary
  • Visualizations in a glace

Context

Evaluating university faculty teaching and research performance is necessary for multiple reasons, including assurance of student learning and informing administrative decision-making.

In this workshop, we will use a simulated dataset consisting of faculty employees information. The data set will be use for learning data visualization in R. The dataset is available in ´xlsx´ and you can download it here.

Content

The dataset contains 32 variables and 850 rows of data. It reports data metrics related to three different dimensions: human resources, teaching performance and research performance.

Element Description
Human Resources
Personal information Personal information of the faculty members
Employmnet information Information related to appointments of faculty members
Teaching
Effectiveness of course delivery The extent to which knowledge presented is valid. Course content includes: course readings, instructor-developed resources, class exercises, clinical practice, and experiments
Effectiveness in Managing Multiple Courses Ability to manage multuple courses
Effectiveness in Mentoring Students Ability to encourage students and to help them understand the factors that contribute to academic success
Research
Productivity in Research Capacity to conduct research that is of a high enough quality to regularly appear in refereed publications and be regularly included in conference presentations
Service
Service to the Institution Involvement in university committees
Service to Society Engaging in community outreach or community engagement effort

Data Dictionary

Variables included in th dataset are defined in the data dictionary.

Variable Description Element
AcadYear Academic year
EmployeeName Faculty’s full name Personal information
Sex Sex (M or F) Personal information
YearBirth Faculty’s year of birth Personal information
Nationality Faculty’s nationality Personal information
Appointment Appointment ranks (1 = Assistant Professor, 2 = Associate Professor, 3 = Professor) Employment information
SchoolApp School of appointment Employment information
FirstYearApp Year of first appointment Employment information
Salary The faculty´s yearly salary ($U.S. Dollars) Employment information
DaysLateLast30 No. of times the faculty was late to work during the year Employment information
Absences No. of times the faculty was absent from work during the year Employment information
JobSatisfaction Results from the last labour satisfaction survey using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 extremely dissatisfied to 5 extremely satisfied) Employment information
SelfEvalResp Results from the last self-assestment survey about spped of response to students using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 extremely slow to 5 extremely fast) Effectiveness of course delivery
SelfEvalTech Results from the last self-assestment survey about the use of instructional technology using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 never to 5 always) Effectiveness of course delivery
SelfEvalInnov Results from the last self-assestment survey about the use of educational innovation approaches using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 never to 5 always) Effectiveness of course delivery
StudentEvalResp Results from the last evaluation by students about spped of response to students using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 extremely slow to 5 extremely fast) Effectiveness of course delivery
StudentEvalTech Results from the last evaluation by students about the use of instructional technology using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 never to 5 always) Effectiveness of course delivery
StudentEvalInnov Results from the last evaluation by students about the use of educational innovation approaches using a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 never to 5 always) Effectiveness of course delivery
CoursesUnd No. of undergraduate courses instructed during the year Effectiveness in managing multiple courses
CoursesGrad No. of graduate courses instructed during the year Effectiveness in managing multiple courses
MentoringResProj No. of students mentored in research during the year Effectiveness in mentoring students
MentoringTheses No. of theses supervised during the year Effectiveness in mentoring students
ResearchArea Faculty’s research area Productivity in research
NumPublications No.of articles published in peer-reviewed journals during the year Productivity in research
SubManuscripts No.of articles submitted to peer-reviewed journals during the year Productivity in research
NumCitations Faculty´s cummulative number of citations Productivity in research
NumBooks No.of books or book chapters published during the year Productivity in research
NumConferences No.of international conferences presentations during the year Productivity in research
ResGrantsAwa No.of research grants submitted Productivity in research
ResGrantsSub No.of research grants awarded Productivity in research
NumComUniv No.of of participations in institutional committee Service to the institution
NumOut No.of of participations in outreach activities Service to the society

Visualizations in a glace

I have developed An application programming interface (API) to explore the visualizations that we will explore in this workshop. To do that, follow these steps:

  1. Download the data set here.

  2. Upload the file.
